data.title: duogram: couple’s first-name initials
data.statement:
Your company makes duogram towels, which are like traditional wedding-present monogramed towels but only has each person's first-initial.
For example Oprah and Stedman would have a duogram of {{O & S}} or {{S & O}} 
(If interested in the tradition about that, see background below)

When a customer rejects/returns an order to you, you might keep it for later resale (or you might not) depending on how common the initials are, and how much warehouse space you have.

The warehouse manager will give you a number [[topNum]], for example {{20}}
This means, you will {{save}} the returned-towels only if there's:
~a man's name in the top 20 of MenList* and
~a woman's name in the top 20 of WomenList*
...that will fit the initials. (Initials can be in either order.)

(*MenList and WomenList are names ranked by popularity, starting with most popular.  Both those lists are in the stub already, for your convenience.)





~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ 
BACKGROUND (<<NOT needed>> to solve the puzzle):
ENGAGED COUPLES
Traditionally it is not appropriate for an engaged couple to use the last name before their wedding ceremony. Instead, use a duogram incorporating the couple’s first-name initials only. Once they are married, they may use the full combined initials.
Source: https://www.vogue.com/article/monogram-etiquette-wedding-registry

Lists are from https://www.ssa.gov/oact/babynames/decades/century.html

testCases.title: Test 1
testCases.testIn:
20
3
O & S
S & J
B & X
testCases.testOut:
O & S = don't save
S & J = save
B & X = don't save

data.stubGenerator:
read topNum:int
read numReturns:int
loop numReturns read initials:string(5)
write answer

Names ranked by popularity

data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> An integer, [[topNum]], the number of top names you will consider
<<Line 2:>> An integer, [[numReturns]], the number of returns you are processing
<<next [[numReturns]] Lines:>> A 5-character-long string, the [[initials]] separated by {{ & }}
